explanation:
- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: Macro used to obtain impl from token. Need its expansion to see whether the call is purely compile-time/invariant or depends on runtime state (and whether it invokes OS_ObjectIndexFromToken). If it is a constant expression the controlling expression could be invariant.
- OS_impl_mutex_table: The table argument to OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET. Its declaration/type/layout determines whether indexing by token yields a runtime-varying pointer or a compile-time constant.
- OS_impl_mutex_internal_record_t: Definition of the struct (especially the type and name of the member 'id'). Required to confirm impl->id type and whether taking its address yields a valid pthread mutex object (affects pthread_mutex_lock behavior and return variability).
- OS_object_token_t: Definition/representation of the token parameter (contents, whether it can be a compile-time constant or expanded to an invariant). Needed to decide if OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(token) can be an invariant.
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: Shown in the static call graph as a callee — likely used by OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET. Its implementation/semantics determine whether the mapping from token to index is runtime-dependent or a constant expression.
- pthread_mutex_lock: Prototype and documented return semantics are crucial to determine whether status = pthread_mutex_lock(&(impl->id)) can produce non-constant results (0 on success, nonzero on error). Without this, one cannot prove the controlling expression (status != 0) is non-invariant.
- pthread_mutex_t: Type of impl->id; needed to verify pthread_mutex_lock is being called on a proper mutex object and whether the lock operation can fail or always returns a fixed value in this build/platform.
- OS_SEM_FAILURE and OS_SUCCESS: Macro/enum definitions used in the return statements. Needed to confirm they are ordinary constants and to reason about the effect of the if-condition and whether any compile-time constant folding could make the condition invariant.

These symbols together let an analyzer determine how 'status' is produced and whether the controlling expression (status != 0) can vary at runtime or is an invariant, which is required to assess compliance with the MISRA C rule on invariant controlling expressions.
